Authors:
Wayne M Pitt, Jacqueline Edwards, Jose R Urbez-Torres,
Florent P Trouillas
Title:
First record of Dothiorella omnivora, and clarification of
the status of Botryosphaeriaceous fungi from grapevines in
Australia
Keywords:
Botryosphaeriaceae  Botryosphaeria dieback  grapevine
trunk diseases
Abstract:
Species of Dothiorella (Botryosphaeriaceae) bear
two-celled conidia that become brown and 1-septate prior to dehiscence
from conidiogenous cells. Based on morphological characters and
phylogeny of DNA sequences of the internal transcribed spacer
(ITS15.8SITS2) region (ITS) and part of the translation elongation
factor 1alpha gene (EF1alpha), Dothiorella omnivora Linaldeddu, Deidda
& Scanu, previously isolated from walnut (Juglans regia L.) in
France and Iran, hazelnut (Corylus avellana L.) and Hop hornbeam (Ostrya
carpinifolia Scop.) in Italy, European ash (Fraxinus excelsior L.) in
Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Lawson cypress (Chamaecyparis lawsoniana (A.
Murray) Parl.) and White cedar (Thuja occidentalis L.) in Serbia, is
reported for the first time in Australia, and for the first time from
grapevines (Vitis vinifera L.). Four species of Dothiorella, and a total
of 15 species of Botryosphaeriaceous fungi are now recognised from
grapevines in Australia.
